es.fnl.fsm
Class Pattern<E>

java.lang.Object
  es.fnl.fsm.Pattern<E>

public class Pattern<E>
extends Object

A generic, NFA-based pattern matching implementation using weighted backtracking and providing capture groups.

This class provides methods to compile a non-deterministic state machine. In addition to this class, the Transition interface has to be implemented, defining how elements on the sequence should be matched and which weight the resulting transition should have.

The entire API for this generic NFA is designed as close as possible to Java's own Pattern API. It is incomplete, because while the class is usable, it provides no static compile(String regex) method. Therefore, some method of compiling the NFA needs to be implemented, such as a regular expression language based on a context free grammar. For this reason, the toString() method that would convert the Pattern back to a String of the regular language only produces a directed, acyclic graph of the state-transitions (i.e., cyclic dependencies are not represented).

Compiling a Pattern

Users of this generic NFA package could, for example, inherit this class and implement a method such as public static Pattern compile(String) that compiles the NFA from some regular expression language. The states should be compiled using the default constructor, and the static methods match (a single transition), chain ("AND", "", i.e., chain a sequence of transitions), and branch ("OR", "|", branch out into several possible transitions). To declare a particular sub-pattern as a capture group, apply the static capture method on it. The core sequence element matching should implement the Transition interface. A pattern's behavior can be augmented by making it optional ("?") and/or by allowing it to be repeated ("+"; a pattern that is made both optional and repeated effectively acts as a Kleene closure, "*"). Unless there are reasons not to, the last step of compiling a pattern should be to call minimize() on itself, thereby removing states with epsilon transitions and no other semantic values (essentially, artifacts from the compilation).

A few convenience methods present in Pattern are not implemented, particularly the split method.

Author:
Florian Leitner

Constructor Detail

Pattern

public Pattern()
Construct the simplest possible NFA: a two-state automata joined by an epsilon transition.

This pattern will match anything, from the empty sequence ("lambda"), to the infinite one. It provides a perfect "seed" for assembling more complex patterns.

Pattern

Pattern(State<E> entry,
        State<E> exit)
Construct an NFA from the given entry and exit states.

It is the responsibility of the user to ensure these two states are actually connected. This particular constructor should therefore only be used internally.

Parameters:
entry - state
exit - state

toString

public final String toString()
A tree-like (multi-line) DAG representation of the NFA's states and transitions for debugging purposes only.

Overrides:
toString in class Object

optional

public final Pattern<E> optional()
Augment this pattern to match zero or one iterations of itself, i.e., the pattern may optionally be skipped.

It is allowed to use both optional() and repeat() on the same pattern.

Returns:
itself/this pattern

repeat

public final Pattern<E> repeat()
Augment this pattern to match one or more repetitions of itself, i.e., the pattern may optionally be matched several times.

It is allowed to use both optional() and repeat() on the same pattern.

Returns:
itself/this pattern

minimize

public final Pattern<E> minimize()
Remove states that only have epsilon transitions and instead connect their source and target states directly. Capture states will never be pruned even if they only have outgoing epsilon transitions.

This method should be used after the entire pattern has been compiled to reduce the total number of transitions and states in the FSM.

Returns:
itself/this pattern

replaceAndExpand

private static final <T> boolean replaceAndExpand(Map<State<T>,Set<State<T>>> expansions,
                                                  Set<State<T>> states)
Expand any invalid states in the given set of states.

Parameters:
expansions - a mapping of invalid states to their target expansions
states - a set of states possibly containing invalid states to be expanded
Returns:
true if any expansion was made

Returns:
a new matcher for this pattern
